name: Tarcísio Fischer
bio: I'm graduated in computer science, currently working on ESSS, where we develop simulation software for engineering. Main interests include numerical methods, numerical analysis, computational methods in engineering, optimization and AI.
title: Solução de problemas de condução de calor transiente em volumes finitos com Python/SciPy
abstract: The author will show a case study applying th FVM (Finite Volume Method) to solve transient, two dimensional, heat conduction problems with nonlinear boundary conditions. The talk's proposal is to guide the audience with implementation and comparisons between scipy's vs petsc4py's nonlinear solvers.
description: O método de volumes finitos é aplicado para resolver problemas de condução de calor transiente em duas dimensões. A proposta da palestra é mostrar o estudo de caso, utilizando as bibliotecas numpy e scipy, e uma comparação entre os solvers não lineares da SciPy e da PETSc (Por meio da biblioteca petsc4py).

name: Sergio Bastos
bio: I am a mechanical engineer that likes to code since the 80's. I have made a study for an electric car sharing system for the city of Curitiba and it was based on a Python simulator that I have developed.
title: Simulating a electric car sharing operation with Python
abstract:
How to write an electric car sharing simulation using Python and Simpy.
The talk is basically to describe this article:
https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/simulating-electric-car-sharing-operation-sergio-bastos/
description: How to write an electric car sharing simulation using Python and Simpy
notes: I am a mechanical engineer that likes to code since the 80's. I have made a study for an electric car sharing system for the city of Curitiba and it was based on a Python simulator that I have developed.

name: Raniere Silva
bio: I work as the Community Officer for the [Software Sustainability Institute](https://www.software.ac.uk/). When possible, I volunteer as a instructor/mentor at some local Python workshops, including [Software Carpentry](https://software-carpentry.org/) and [Django Girls Manchester](https://djangogirls.org/manchester). As part of my work and volunteer activities, I'm always looking for ways to improve the relationship between novice developers and their more experience fellows. In my spare time, I like to read sci-fi.
title: Research Software Engineer
abstract: A growing number of people in academia combine expertise in programming with an intricate understanding of research. Although this combination of skills is extremely valuable, these people lack a formal place in the academic system. Are you of those people? Yes, you are a Research Software Engineer.
description:
Are you doing the work of a Research Software Engineer? If you answer yes to many of the following questions, you are.

1. Are you employed to develop software for research?
2. Are you spending more time developing software than conducting research?
3. Are you employed as a postdoctoral researcher, even though you predominantly work on software development?
4. Are you the person who does computers in your research group?
5. Are you sometimes not named on research papers despite playing a fundamental part in developing the software used to create them?
6. Do you lack the metrics needed to progress your academic career, like papers and conference presentations, despite having made a significant contribution through software?

This talk will cover the use of the term Research Software Engineer (RSE) from its inception during one workshop promoted by the Software Sustainability Institute in 2012 until today when it is used to represent a community of over 1,200 RSEs and spawned imitators in Australia, Germany, the Netherlands and Norway, with Canada, South Africa, and the US.
notes: No technical requirements. No conflict of interest.

name: Olemis Lang
bio: Olemis has +10 years of experience in the technology development sector with experience ranging from programming of embedded systems and 3D graphics, implementation of fieldbus protocols, application development (mobile , desktop, web, hybrid) to design of big data solutions and supporting DevOps activities . Olemis is Senior Software Engineer at Skycoin, founded the CubanTech Group, collaborates with the Apache Bloodhound project and is a member of the Python-Cuba work group of the Python Software Foundation .
organization: Senior Software Engineer at Skycoin, Executive VicePresident at LatamTech Foundation
title: Programming microcontrollers for IoT with MicroPython
abstract: MicroPython is emerging as an option to quickly program micro-controllers used to prototype hardware in early design stages. The workshop introduces MicroPython, basic concepts, and supported devices. Hands-on lab covers network programming, MQTT, and exercises with LED, buttons, and servo motors.
description:
## Programming microcontrollers for IoT with MicroPython

Workshop outline is as follows :

- Overview of MicroPython (15 min - talk)
- Hands-on labs : Network programming, MQTT (10 min)
- Hands-on labs : Exercises with LED (10 min)
- Hands-on labs : Exercises with buttons (10 min)
- Hands-on labs : Exercises with servo motors (10 min)
- Final example : Simple device able to interact with a virtual world (5 min)

### Required setup

- Download [MicroPython web REPL](https://github.com/micropython/webrepl).
- Install a [terminal emulator software](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_emulator) able to connect to serial devices.
- Install a [text editor software](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text_editor) or [integrated development environment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_development_environment) of your preference.
  * We'll be editing Python code, if you are using an IDE make sure you have the corresponding language tools installed
- Bring your laptop !
notes:
Needed space and resources
Videobeam
Sound equipment (Microphone and speakers)
Whiteboard
Tables for 4,6,8 people
University chairs
Resource urls in case you have already did a similar workshop (photos, videos, notes), organizers official pages


Slides are available at http://slides.cuban.tech/micropython.html . This will give a better idea.

We offer this workshop in Cuba quite often e.g.

- [CubanTech Meetup #20 - PyDay La Habana, Cuba](https://www.meetup.com/CubanTech/events/242652841/)
- [CubanTech Meetup #26 - MicroPython PyDay with Tarek Ziadé Association Francophone Python a.k.a AFPy, in La Habana, Cuba](https://www.meetup.com/CubanTech/events/245032996/)

We've done in Cuba [Nodeschool Nodebots](http://nodebots.io/) workshop many times:

- [Nodeschool Nodebots NYJS workshop at University of Sancti Spiritus, Cubas](http://meetup.cuban.tech/events/244272743/)
- [Nodeschool Nodebots NYJS workshop in Havana, Cuba](http://meetup.cuban.tech/events/242652841/)
- [Nodeschool Nodebots NYJS workshop in Island of Youth, Cuba](http://meetup.cuban.tech/events/241706888/)
- [Nodeschool Nodebots NYJS workshop in Holguín, Cuba](http://meetup.cuban.tech/events/235953812/)

... and even in Golang

- [Gophers Cuba Blockchain from scratch. ESP8266 Skycoin wallet, in Isla de la Juventud, Cuba](https://www.meetup.com/CubanTech/events/251523453/)

Proposed workshop is very similar but using MicroPython to program ESP8266, Adafruit Huzzah and PyBoard micro-controllers instead of Raspberry Pi SBC to program Arduino with [johnny-five](http://johnny-five.io/) .

name: João Sebastião de Oliveira Bueno
bio: João S. O. Bueno é desenvolvedor Python há mais de 15 anos, e sempre se interessou pela criação de imagens computacionais, usando diversos aplicativos e bibliotecas. É colaborador do GNU Image Manipulation Program (GIMP) desde 2004. Profissionalmente desenvolve aplicações Python backend em empresas de tecnologia. Já palestrou em dezenas de eventos de informática, com temas que vão do aprendizado de programação para iniciantes, até tópicos avançados com Python, alternando-os com temas de edição e tratamento de imagens e criação de plug-ins para o GIMP.
title: Plotando dados do zero: Customizando seus resultados com Python
abstract: Como usar Python para gerar plotagens e infográficos sem usar as bibliotecas de plotagem tradicionais. Entender o passo a passo da criação de um plot, usando bibliotecas básicas, ou criar a saída para uma visualização em 3D ou animação pode mudar a percepção dos seus resultados para vários públicos.
description:
Plotagem Customizada
=====================

As vezes precisamos de uma plotagem de dados mais impactante. Dependendo do público alvo, ou mesmo para uma melhor visualização dos resultados, gráficos com cores variadas, plotagens em um campo 3D usando texturas, iluminação e transparência, podem fazer toda a diferença em comunicar os resultados de uma pesquisa.

Os vários pacotes científicos do Python são integrados com bibliotecas para plotagem de dados acadêmicas consagradas e padronizadas. No entanto, nem sempre a saída obtida por essas bibliotecas padrão, como a matplotlib, ggplot e seus derivados tem um resultado final agradável. Embora quase sempre tenham o resultado mais acurado, geram uma saida visualmente estéril dos dados, mais preocupada em exatidão das medidas e label-ticks:os interessados nessas medidas podem bem visualizar os dados diretamente na forma numérica - a principal intenção de plotagem de gráficos é justamente tornar os resultados mais atraentes. 

Python é uma linguagem de programação completa, que integra e manipula dados em mais domínios do que estamos acostumados. Nesta apresentação, teremos uma demonstração de como criar alguns tipos de gráficos a partir do zero, em várias bibliotecas que disponibilizam apenas uma API 2D simples, o que nos permite customizar cores e formas. Exemplos de bibliotecas que podem ser usadas são a Pygame, tkinter e pillow. 

É possível também usar mecanismos de template de texto do Python para gerar saídas de gráficos diferenciados em 2D, gerando diretamente código Postscript e 3D com texturas foto-realistas, transparências e sombras gerando arquivos para o renderizador Povray.

Dentre outras possibilidades, esses mecanismos também permitem a criação de gráficos animados, permitindoa  incorporação de uma dimensão a mais aos dados, ou comparando séries diferentes elaborando-se alguma forma de transição entre as mesmas. 

Espera-se que o público entenda a ideia de que a visualização de seus resultados não está limitada aos temas padronizados que acompanham as bibliotecas de postagem, e que sempre é possível apresentar os gráficos de forma bastante estética e chamativa, usando toda a flexibilidade que o Python proporciona.
notes:
Esta palestra pode ser bastante útil tanto para pesquisadores querendo mostrar seus resultados para um público diferente do público acadêmico, como para perceber a possibilidade de plotar resultados em tipos de gráficos ainda não existentes nas bibliotecas existentes.

Também é interessante para estudantes e professores perceberem que ao escreverem suas próprias rotinas para um criação de um plot, se dá um entendimento muito melhor de quais realmente são as grandezas envolvidas, e do significado dos dados do que escrever `plt.plot(...)` e ver um resultado padronizado, mas com pouco significado. 

O palestrante é desenvolvedor Python há mais de 15 anos, e tem grande interesse nas áreas de criação de imagens e bibliotecas gráficas.

name: Ariel Rossanigo
bio:
I'm Computer engineer since 2006 and I like everything related to Artificial Inteligence, Machine Learning and DataScience.
I teach Artificial Inteligence (among other subjects) since 2006.
I'm a member of PyAr since 2005, and from that time I use Python to teach and work.
I'm from Rafaela, Santa Fe, Argentina.
title: My scientific python toolbox
abstract: When starting a new project, it's fundamental to use the right tools. The aim of this talk is to show some of the main characteristics of the tools that I use in projects related to data and machine learning.
description:
When starting a new project, it's fundamental to use the right tools. The aim of this talk is to show some of the main characteristics of the tools that I use in projects related to data and machine learning. 

The main subjects we will cover in the talk are: programming environment, data processing, visualizations and Machine Learning.
notes:
I've been working in data science and machine learning projects for more than 4 years and several times people asked about how to start, what tools they need  to learn. The aim of this talk is to be the answer to that questions, like an introduction to Python and Data related projects. 

I'm able to perform the talk in Spanish or English.

name: Eduardo Sánchez
bio:
Eduardo Sánchez is the head of Havana Blockchain Center, an non-profit that educates developers, researchers, government officials and communities on the impact of DLT in Cuban society. Mr. Sánchez presented last year at the Latin American Bitcoin & Blockchain Conferences and at the One Young World Summit. He has worked at blockchain companies like Skycoin, and currently gives technical & non-technical workshops on DLT to developers around Cuba. 
Mr. Sánchez has a B.S. in Computer Science, defending the first Diploma Thesis on blockchain technologies at the University of Havana. He is a Young Leaders of the Americas Initiative (YLAI) Fellow and a One Young World Ambassador.
title: Let's build a blockchain! Coding a mini-cryptocurrency in Python
abstract: The topic of blockchain and DLT has exploded over the past 18 months, with a market cap of almost $300bn as of July 2018. We will learn how to build a cryptocurrency from scratch, analyzing the components that power a blockchain, and the advantages of a decentralized, crypto-secured structure.
description:
In this workshop, we will begin by asking ourselves the reasons to build a digital currency. We'll review the postulates of the cypherpunks and their motives to develop a currency for the internet, with a focus on privacy and security. Then we'll try to build a digital currency in the most intuitive way. 
We'll start out by coding a naïve, centralized, PayPal-like digital currency. The shortcomings of this approach will be exposed: it's serious risks regarding reliability and security. We'll conclude this weaknesses emerge from it's centralized nature, and we'll try to rethink our digital currency to avoid a single point of failure. 
Subsecuently, we'll review decentralized protocols, moving from a server/client structure to a gossip protocol. As we test it out, we'll notice that, even when we have achieved fault-tolerance, we still lack Byzantine-fault tolerance (BFT). 
To establish an effective method of authentication, we'll introduce the concept of cryptographic identities, and learn the basics of public-key cryptography for asserting a message's authenticity. 
After integrating asymmetric encryption into our gossip protocol, we'll notice we still suffer the double-spend problem. We'll review a few approaches to solving the double-spend problem, most of them using centralized architectures, taking us to the first shortcomings we explored. 
At this point, we'll realize the main issue with decentralized protocols is that often, peers can't agree on the timing of certain events. We'll conclude we'll need to implement a decentralized timestamping server, and here we'll introduce the blockchain as a data structure that provides a notion of order among its blocks, while making it very hard to change that order thanks to the Proof-of-Work consensus mechanism. 
During the implementation of the blockchain, we'll look at the elements that form it, such as the notion of mining and the fork resolution methods (longest chain rule). 
As the workshop has a limited timespan, we'll have to skip a few topics, such as the economics of cryptocurrencies, the concept of merkle trees, SPVs, as well as smart contracts and other DLT like hashgraph or tangle.
Nevertheless, at the end of the workshop, the audience will have a basic understanding of the work of blockchain technologies, which are becoming mainstream in the coordination of human activity, and a key player in current and future approaches to emerging technologies such as distributed computing and AI (paramount tools for computer scientists in the 21st century).
notes: Basic knowledge of Python programming is required for a full understanding of the workshop. Participants should have access to a computer with a copy of a Python 3 installation and connection to a shared network. This workshop in partially inspired by Haseeb Qureshi's "A mini-crytocurrency in Ruby".

name: Déborah Mesquita
bio:
I’m a Data Scientist and a MSc student in Natural Language Processing and Data Visualization.
I think I do my best work when I create and develop ideas that connect things from different areas, like that time I won the Azure Machine Learning Award by using a model to help kids with math. Or when I created an app to develop the suburbs of my city (Recife, Brazil) using tourism and was admitted into the MIT Global Entrepreneurship Bootcamp. I LOVE to write and explain things. One of my goals is helping to demystify Computer Science concepts :)
title: Investigando o que um modelo aprende ao classificar sentenças de artigos científicos
abstract: Hoje em dia a maioria dos classificadores em ML permanecem caixas-preta. Saber a causa das predições pode ser útil para aumentar a confiança e oferecer insights que ajudam a melhorar a acurácia do modelo. Nesta palestra vamos ver como explicas as predições de qualquer classificador utilizando o LIME
description: Entender porque um classificador produziu determinada predição representa um avanço importante para a implantação de modelos de Aprendizagem de Máquina no mundo real. Você confiaria em um modelo com 90% de acurácia mas que aprendeu a classificar as instâncias a partir de algum noise nos dados? O algoritmo LIME busca resolver o problema de explicar predições para qualquer classificador, independente do algoritmo de predição utilizado. Dada uma instância x o algoritmo gera samples a partir da perturbação de x e consegue explicar localmente a predição. Nesta palestra vamos aprender a utilizar o LIME através do estudo de caso de um classificador treinado para identificar funções retóricas das sentenças de artigos científicos.
notes:
Eu gosto muito de explicar conceitos da área de Computação para pessoas que não necessariamente da área. Como praticamente a maioria dos pesquisadores hoje em dia estão começando a utlizar algum modelo de predição nas suas pesquisas, essa ferramenta pode ser de grande valia para todos e sou uma boa escolha para ajudar a difundi-lá :)
No projeto eu utilizei o spaCy, scikit-learn e o LIME, os três escritos em Python. Para acompanhar a palestra é ideal que se tenha ao menos uma noção do que são modelos de predição, mas nada muito aprofundado. This talk can be delivered in English too if required :)

name: Ariel Rossanigo
bio:
I'm Computer engineer since 2006 and I like everything related to Artificial Inteligence, Machine Learning and DataScience.

title: Image processing with deep learning
abstract:
This talk is an introduction to deep learning and the kind of layers and networks used to perform image processing.
During the talk a complete classification example will be done using Keras.
description:
This talk is an introduction to deep learning and the kind of layers and networks used to perform image processing.
During the talk a complete clasification example will be done using Keras. 

Agenda:

* Machine Learning, 
* Neuronal Networks, Deep Learning
* Convolution layers
* MaxPooling, DropOut, DenseLayers
* Classification example 
* Filter visualization

name: Olemis Lang
bio: Olemis has +10 years of experience in the technology development sector with experience ranging from programming of embedded systems and 3D graphics, implementation of fieldbus protocols, application development (mobile , desktop, web, hybrid) to design of big data solutions and supporting DevOps activities . Olemis is Senior Software Engineer at Skycoin, founded the CubanTech Group, collaborates with the Apache Bloodhound project and is a member of the Python-Cuba work group of the Python Software Foundation .
organization: Senior Software Engineer at Skycoin, Executive VicePresident at LatamTech Foundation
title: Hands-on : Desplegando aplicaciones web, GUI y Raspberry Pi (IoT) con Docker
abstract: La virtualización de aplicaciones es una herramienta indispensable para el despliegue de centros de datos, entornos de trabajo, aplicaciones web, big data, e Internet de las Cosas (IoT). Docker es una de las tecnologías líderes en esta rama. El taller introduce el uso de Docker en varias plataformas
description:
Este taller en cuestión se realizará en Sancti Spiritus. Estamos muy entusiasmados con el hecho de poder darle la bienvenida a nuevos miembros de la comunidad. Por eso ofreceremos un día completo dedicado a que Usted #AprendaDocker. Sí, #learnDocker .

 ** ¿Es Ud un usuario avanzado? ** Le recomendamos a todos los conocedores y amantes de Docker, sin distinción de niveles de habilidades, que participen de este encuentro. Necesitamos una red de mentores que entiendan la plataforma de contenedores y que respondan las preguntas que los principiantes puedan tener. Haga click acá para [aplicar como mentor](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1GaPoybbMps5OyVIz8Tjj3YYhOlvYROqR6EyeyPrU-fE) .

## Agenda:

- SSH into a container
- Build an image
- Docker Volume
- Linked containers
- Using docker-compose
- Scale containers with docker-compose
- Share an image (share this presentation)
- Package an app with its environment
- Screen and sound within containers (x-forward)
- Intro to Hypriot OS
- Explore Hypriot OS Docker platform on Raspberry Pi
- Deploy web apps on Raspberry Pi
- Let's get physical !!!

Mientras se acerca la fecha del evento compartiremos a través de los canales [CubanTech](https://telegram.me/cubantech) y [Docker Cuba](https://telegram.me/dockercuba) de Telegram más información acerca de los materiales necesarios y las recomendaciones de preparativos previos al taller. Se ofrecerán varios recursos (libros, instaladores, artefactos, videos tutoriales, videos de conferencias) que le ayudarán a profundizar conocimientos sobre las herramientas, ecosistemas de trabajo y casos de éxito de su aplicación por medianas y grandes empresas de renombre internacional.

## Traiga: 

Su laptop y documento de identidad en el caso que sea preciso mostrarlo para entrar a la sede. Un dispositivo de almacenamiento para copiar los videos, documentación e imágenes de Docker que ofrecemos a los participantes. Laptop para completar los talleres. Si tiene Raspberry Pi que quiera instalar con Hypriot OS , la puede traer también . Le ayudaremos con el proceso.

## Prepare: 

Recomendamos [instalar Docker CE](https://docs.docker.com/engine/installation/) . ¡No se lo pierda! 

Si desea utilizar versiones anteriores o su equipo no cumple las condiciones para instalar versiones recientes de Docker, por favor lea las instrucciones siguientes.

Los usuarios Linux deben instalar [Docker engine](https://docs.docker.com/engine/installation/) 1.12 o superior y [Docker compose](https://docs.docker.com/compose/install/) 1.8 o superior.

Los usuarios de Mac OS X deben tener en cuenta que las versiones recientes de Docker exigen [varios requisitos](https://docs.docker.com/engine/installation/mac/#docker-for-mac) para poder ejecutar los contenedores. Si su laptop no los cumpliera, descargue [Docker Toolbox para Mac](https://www.docker.com/products/docker-toolbox) y siga las instrucciones de instalación. 

Los usuarios de Windows 10 Pro deben instalar [Docker for Windows](https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-windows/). De utilizar otra versión instale [Docker toolbox](https://docker.github.io/toolbox/) . 

Alternativamente puede instalar una herramienta de virtualización y crear una máquina virtual de GNU/Linux. La variante recomendada es seguir [los pasos de la guía de instalación](https://www.virtualbox.org/manual/ch02.html) de [VirtualBox](https://www.virtualbox.org/) y [crear una máquina virtual de Ubuntu](http://www.simplehelp.net/2015/06/09/how-to-install-ubuntu-on-your-mac/) , pues los repositorios estarán disponibles en la red local en la dirección http://ubuntu.cuban.tech . Habrá también repositorios de Debian en http://debian.cuban.tech

Todos estos recursos serán ofrecidos para descarga durante el evento pero, de ser posible, le sugerimos adelantar la instalación .
notes:
Needed space and resources
Videobeam
Sound equipment (Microphone and speakers)
Whiteboard
Tables for 4,6,8 people
University chairs


Resource urls in case you have already did a similar workshop (photos, videos, notes), organizers official pages

Slides available at http://slides.cuban.tech/docker-intro.html . This will give a better idea.

We offer this workshop in Cuba quite often . Many events like this in the past listed in [Docker Cuba meetup instance](http://docker.cuban.tech) .

name: Alizishaan Khatri
bio:
Alizishaan's professional passions revolve around two things : using technology to solve real-world problems and sharing solutions with the community. Over the summer of 2017, he designed and built an offensive content detection system for a Silicon Valley company. Past industry projects include a price-prediction system for cars and a status communication system that minimized false alerts. He is currently employed as a Machine Learning Engineer. 

Outside of work, Alizishaan's passions include mountaineering, skiing, travelling and photography.
title: Detecting offensive messages using Deep Learning: A micro-service based approach
abstract:
What are you doing to control abusive content on your platform? Can your current solution tell the difference between "f\*\*king awesome" and "f\*\*king loser"? Can it detect racist and sexist content?

You will learn how to build a deep learning based solution and deploy it as a micro-service.
description:
Offensive / abusive content is a major issue for social-media and digital interaction platforms. In some jurisdictions (Eg: Europe), platform providers are required to remove such content within 24 hours of posting or risk hefty fines (upto €50M in Germany). In order to meet the governance mandate, we need to have systems in place that can automatically detect abusive content at scale. This talk is based on my practical experience of building an automated solution to solve this problem.

This talk begins with discussing some of the approaches currently being employed in industry for offensive content detection at scale: word filtering, rule-based systems and actual human annotation.

The former two are restricted by the following:

-   Offensive content is context specific. A given word (f\*ck) can be used in both positive (that’s f\*cking awesome) and negative ((that’s f\*cking terrible)) contexts.
-   Robustness to spelling variations (The word ‘shit’ can be spelt as ‘sh\*t’, ‘sh!t’, 'shiite', etc)
-   Failure to detect content that is offensive in idea but uses non-offensive words. (Eg: your mom is a fat cow, X people are inferior, etc)

Manual human annotation is notoriously hard and expensive to scale. The talk presents a Deep neural network based approach to overcome the previously mentioned limitations. It introduces and discusses the building blocks of model architecture (deep convolutional networks, word embeddings, etc).

The second half of the talk focuses on implementing the above model to solve the problem at scale as a RESTful micro-service using python, Django, Tensorflow and Docker. This architecture can also be used to implement other text classification systems as well (eg: user intent detection systems, topic-of-discussion classifiers, etc.), making the talk relevant for a wider user base.

Attendees will:

-   Gain insights into building deep learning based text-classification systems that can scale
-   Learn the nitty gritties of the offensive content detection and text classification
-   Learn about the basic concepts of Deep Learning and NLP (convolutional neural nets, multi-layer perceptron, word embeddings, etc.)
-   Understand the scientific and software challenges involved in text classification and learn to overcome them
-   Be able to apply the learnings from here to solve other text classification problems at scale
tags,rating: ['python', 'deep learning', 'machine learning', 'data science', 'devops', 'neural networks', 'microservice', 'containers', 'science', 'Emerging Computing Technologies']

name: LucianoFromTrelew
bio:
Computer Science student from Trelew, Chubut, Argentina. Linux and Python enthusiast. I also like frontend development :D

Indian Pale Ale FTW!
title: Datawarehousing para datos genéticos, socioeconómicos y fenotípicos, con visualización 3D
abstract: Se presenta una aplicación para el almacenamiento, análisis, y visualización interactiva de datos heterogéneos pertenecientes al biobanco de la Patagonia (proyecto RAICES), basado en herramientas libres como Django Rest Framework, Vue.js, Bokeh, THREE.js, y contenedores de Docker
description:
El Instituto Patagónico de Ciencias Sociales y Humanas de  Ciencias Sociales y Humanas ([IPCSH-CONICET](http://www.ipcsh.conicet.gob.ar/)) estudia cómo se relacionan las costumbres y herencias de la región con variables físicas de interés médico, en particular con rasgos de riesgo para enfermedades complejas como obesidad, sobrepeso y síndrome metabólico, entre otras. 

El proyecto [RAICES](https://www.facebook.com/proyecto.raices.patagonia/) (iniciativa propia del IPCSH-CONICET) busca generar un banco de datos genéticos o biobanco de la Patagonia que pueda servir para futuras aplicaciones en el diseño de políticas públicas de salud.

Este trabajo, realizado a través de una pasantía promovida por el Laboratorio de Ciencias de las Imágenes (LCI) de la Universidad Nacional del Sur, presenta la implementación de un datawarehouse (basado en Python y MongoDB) que permite a los investigadores del proyecto almacenar, consultar y analizar datos heterogéneos propios de la colecta (encuestas socioeconómicas, información geográfica y genética, hábitos alimenticios, modelos 3D, vídeos de cuerpo completo, medidas antropométricas, entre otros). Dado que las fuentes de datos eran diversas, se trabajó en un módulo de *ETL* (*Extract, Transform and Load*) para normalizar los datos y adaptarlos al modelo del datawarehouse.

Junto con el datawarehouse se diseñó y desarrolló una [aplicación web](https://youtu.be/CIpbHRLAG0I) para la carga masiva de datos y acceso a los mismos en forma selectiva, brindando también una plataforma interactiva de visualización de datos exploratoria (gráficos y modelos 3D). 

Se tiene como resultado un framework fácilmente generalizable basado en tecnologías libres  disponible para ser utilizado en otros ámbitos científicos

Las tecnologías utilizadas para el desarrollo del trabajo fueron las siguientes:

- [Django Rest Framework](http://www.django-rest-framework.org/) (desarrollo de una API REST)
- [Vue.js](https://vuejs.org/) (cliente web)
- [Bokeh](https://bokeh.pydata.org/en/latest/) (visualización de gráficos 2D)
- [THREE.js](https://threejs.org/) (visualización 3D)
- [Pandas](https://pandas.pydata.org/), [pyocr](https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/OpenPaperwork/pyocr), y [pillow](https://python-pillow.org/) (módulo de ETL)
- [Mongoengine](http://mongoengine.org/) (comunicación con la base de datos)
- [Docker](https://www.docker.com/) (puesta en producción de todo el sistema)
notes:
Somos dos estudiantes (Luciano Serruya Aloisi y Pablo Toledo Margalef) de la Licenciatura en Sistemas de la UNPSJB próximos a recibirnos (2019/2020), con gran interés en el desarrollo de software (en Python, principalmente) y en su aplicación en la ciencia y en la investigación.

Este trabajo fue realizado a través de una pasantía promovida por el Laboratorio de Ciencias de las Imágenes (LCI) de la Universidad Nacional del Sur.

Durante el 2017 y 2018, dimos las siguientes charlas en el [Patagonia Python Meetup](https://www.meetup.com/Patagonia-Python-Meetup/):

- Septiembre de 2017:
    - [Análisis de datos con Pandas](https://papablo.github.io/slides/intropandas2017/)
    - [Patrones de Diseño en Python](https://github.com/LucianoFromTrelew/meetup-pd)
- Marzo de 2018:
    - [Deploy de aplicaciones Python en Heroku](https://github.com/PaPablo/twitter-bot-hero)
    - [Cómo publicar Python en PIP](https://github.com/LucianoFromTrelew/cloneme)

name: Raniere Silva
bio: I work as the Community Officer for the [Software Sustainability Institute](https://www.software.ac.uk/). When possible, I volunteer as a instructor/mentor at some local Python workshops, including [Software Carpentry](https://software-carpentry.org/) and [Django Girls Manchester](https://djangogirls.org/manchester). As part of my work and volunteer activities, I'm always looking for ways to improve the relationship between novice developers and their more experience fellows. In my spare time, I like to read sci-fi.
title: A Jupyter Enhancement Proposal Story
abstract:
If you use Jupyter
and don't like something on it,
you should know that you can contribute your idea to enhance the project.
At this talk you will learn how to submit a Jupyter Enhancement Proposals
and share your idea.
description:
Python users should be familiar with the concept of
[Python Enhancement Proposals (PEPs)](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/),
the way that the Python language evolves over time.
In a similar fashion,
the Jupyter project has [Jupyter Enhancement Proposals (JEPs)](https://github.com/jupyter/enhancement-proposals).
This talk with cover the proposer first hand experience
when submiting [JEP 23 - Add Template as Metatada enhancement proposal](https://github.com/jupyter/enhancement-proposals/pull/23)
from it's begin,
during [EuroPython 2017](https://ep2017.europython.eu/),
until the current status of it.
notes: This talk was accepted at EuroPython2018. No technical requirements. No conflict of interest.

name: Arthur Fortes da Costa
bio:
PhD candidate at the Institute of Mathematical and Computational Sciences, University of São Paulo. Graduated in Computer Science from the Faculty CEUT and master's degree in Computer Science from the University of São Paulo (2015). I am also member of Grupy of São Carlos (Grupy-Sanca).

My research interests include Recommender Systems, Data Science, Web Development and Customization and adaptation of content.
title: A Guide to Understand and Build a Recommender System Engine
abstract: This talk aims to present the main concepts and development of Recommender Systems elements for developers who wish to generate personalized content for users based on their interactions - an overview of the development. The talk will also introduce a Python recommender framework, called CaseRec.
description:
## Context and Motivation

From 2005 to 2020, the information in the digital universe will grow by a factor of 300, from 130 exabytes to 40,000 exabytes, or 40 trillion gigabytes (more than 5,200 gigabytes for every man, woman, and child in 2020) [1]. It is simply not possible to grasp even a small percentage of it in a single lifetime, there is too much information to process and to choose. The expression Information Overload was introduced to describe the sensation of fatigue and distress that follows the cognitive surplus required to handle the volume of information we have to deal with every day. Recommender Systems (RS) have emerged in response to the information overload problem by learning from users about their interests from past user actions (ratings, votes, ranked lists, mouse clicks, page views, product purchases, etc.) and suggesting products that are likely to fit their needs.

Many e-commerce and social media companies are leveraging the power of data science and boosting sales by implementing Recommender Systems on their platforms. This approach aim to predict users’ interests and recommend products that quite likely are interesting for them. In this context, this talk aims to provide support for professionals and researchers to know fundamental concepts about recommender systems, as well as the use in practice of techniques of recommendation and evaluation of these systems in their research and applications, aiming at personalization and optimization of the user experience in their systems.. The talk will also serve to introduce a Python recommender framework, called CaseRec [2]. The framework implements the well-knows and state-of-the-art recommendation algorithms in rating prediction and item recommendation scenario, with several evaluation methodologies.

## Rationale of Interest and Audience Attraction

The growing amount of information available on the web and the technological advancement with new e-business services and social networks have provided a content overload to users, providing the emergence of Recommender Systems. Currently, these systems play a key role in sites such as Americanas, Amazon, YouTube, Netflix, Spotify and Social Networks (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and LinkedIn), in order to attract and loyalty users.

In this context, this talk is intended for professionals and academics from research areas related to user experience who wish to use Recommender Systems in their research and applications, but find conceptual or practical difficulties in the development of their applications. The participants will gain insight on how to develop and evaluate the recommendation tools in practice.

## Topics

* Recommender Systems Overview
* Filtering Paradigms
* Generating Users and Items Representations
* Neighborhood and Matrix Factorization Models 
* Tools and Evaluation

## References

[1] https://www.emc.com/leadership/digital-universe/2012iview/

[2] https://github.com/ArthurFortes/CaseRecommender/
notes:
## Requirements

### Participants

Due the focus of this tutorial is on presenting concepts and developing recommender approaches for participants with no previous experience, no prerequisite knowledge of programming languages or specific software is required. For the practical examples, the Python language and its scientific libraries will be used and explained: NumPy, SciPy, Sklearn e Pandas.

### Computational and audio-visual resources

Regarding the computational and audio-visual resources required, it would be interesting, but not impeding, that each participant have access to a personal computer capable of executing and processing commands in Python [https://www.python.org], preferably using the Linux operating system. It would be more attractive for participants to be able to run the examples themselves that will be made available through GitHub [https://github.com/]. For presentation, only one projector and one projection screen will be required.

name: Daniel Severo
title: Ad-hoc Big Data Analysis with Dask
abstract: Ever had memory and performance issues while trying to use pandas, numpy and sklearn? You probably tried to side-step this by migrating to some other module like pyspark, but it just isn't as friendly. What if I told you you could scale all 3 almost effortlessly with Dask and absolutely 0 cost?
description:
Creating custom reports and machine learning models with pandas can be cumbersome with limited hardware resources (memory and CPU). Financial constraints can make spawning cloud instances to side-step this issue a problem, while adding the complexity of libraries such as Apache Spark isn't worth the trouble and staggers data exploration. How can we keep the simplicity and power of pandas, while extending it to be out-of-core and parallel?

Enter Dask: a flexible parallel computing library for analytic computing. With it we will create a linear regression model to predict read time in Medium posts using a Kaggle dataset, while comparing the equivalent implementation with pandas.
notes:
I've been using the SciPy stack and sklearn since 2013, and Dask since 2017. I found that it has solved most of my performance issues when trying to do data exploration, cleaning and general EDA while trying to build machine learning models and create custom reports in big data companies like Chaordic.

I have also contributed to Dask and Dask-ml:
- https://github.com/dask/dask-ml/pull/9
- https://github.com/dask/dask/pull/2710

The only technical requirements for this talk would be that each person have their own laptop computer.
